timeline.bodyText: why is this not directly inside Expressions.equal, so we can avoid duplication between spark 2 and 3?
timeline.author: jackye1995

replies.bodyText: I thought to reject NaN in any predicate and let SparkFilters to do rewrites was the conclusion we reached in this thread?
replies.author: yyanyy

replies.bodyText: Yes, I agree. Rewriting filters should be done in translation to Iceberg so that we have simpler behavior and strong assumptions.
replies.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: I think we should also try to test it for spark2, maybe update some tests in TestReadProjection?
timeline.author: jackye1995
timeline.diffHunk: @@ -49,8 +49,8 @@ public TestSelect(String catalogName, String implementation, Map<String, String>

replies.bodyText: Yeah I actually also spent some time on this but wasn't able to find a good place to add in spark2, and later gave up thinking that the added logic was relatively simple anyway. To me TestReadProjection is more about testing projection which is not what we are doing. I guess I'll create a TestSelect in spark3 test suite and duplicate this class then.
replies.author: yyanyy

replies.bodyText: Added a TestSelect in spark2 by basically duplicating logic from the same class in spark3; although apart from basic sanity testing I'm not sure how helpful the tests are as some of the logic for examine pushed-down filters only exist in spark3...
replies.author: yyanyy

timeline.bodyText: This should be moved into the else block because literal should not allow creating a NaN literal.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't this be is_nan(float) instead of = NaN?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: This is because in DescribeExpressionVisitor  we translate is_nan to = NaN in here. Do you want me to change this to is_nan(float)?
replies.author: yyanyy

replies.bodyText: Yes, I think so. The description shouldn't produce a predicate that we don't support!
replies.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Shouldn't this validate more than just the number of scans?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Yes, sorry I forgot to revisit this after cleaning up other changes. Since in spark2 we don't have Spark3Util.describe() I wasn't sure to which level we want to assert the expression, so that we can still have test coverage without being too coupled with internal implementation. Let me know how you think the updated test is!
replies.author: yyanyy

timeline.bodyText:
This seems brittle because it uses types to place the results.
Other tests use StructProjection and StructLikeSet for similar validations. The incoming row is wrapped to be a StructLike and added to a StructLikeSet based on the expected schema. Then another StructLikeSet is created with the expected rows, which are projected using StructProjection and the expected schema. That is a cleaner way to do this, I think.
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Looks like this uses a Java bean record class, so you could also rely on Spark to convert to your record class, and then use a special comparison function to only compare expected columns.
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Sounds good, I wanted to scope this Record class to only be used for this class' use cases but this is definitely not clean. I changed this to use Spark for converting to Java bean, but encountered a similar issue as described in this post that when projecting a subset of columns, conversion doesn't work due to missing expected columns. Since in this class I'm just projecting one column with primitive type, I convert data frame into their specific classes instead. Please let me know if you know better ways of doing this!
replies.author: yyanyy
